titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0140, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Four gospels in Armenian. Eusebian section numbers in the margins against the text. Concordances in the lower margins. Pentecostal lection numbers. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Arm. 23.
Marginal vignettes contain a portrait, arabesques, birds, flowers, and medallions.

minItem.minDesc: John the Baptist, Portrait: John stands in the right margin, his hand extended to indicate the adjacent text.

headpieces.p: Headpieces at each gospel's opening of bird, floral, and foliate motifs in red, green, blue, and black (pp. 1, 211, 341, 545).

initials.p: Major initials of Matthew, Mark, and Luke's opening lines (30-60 mm) are composed of beads and leaves. John's opening initial (100 mm) is formed by his eagle symbol. Minor initials are formed by figures of birds or flowers.

foliation.p: 1-682. Modern pagination in Arabic numerals in pencil.

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 145 x 100 mm (p. 49). Each column is 145 x 45 mm with a space of 10 mm between.

layout.p: 2 columns, 17 to 19 lines. Ruling with hard point. Pricking in outer margins.

handDesc.p: Written chiefly in bolorgir script in dark brown ink.

condition.p: Water stains. Some retracing of faded text. Several leaves lost.

binding.p: Bound in pigskin over boards. Fore-edge flap. Nail holes are present and the outlines of crosses once attached. Doublures of unbleached linen.

origin.p: The manuscript was written in Armenia and completed in 1609 (Armenian Era 1058) by the priest Karapēt (Garabed) Xanghaluc‛i (his colophon, pp. 681-682). It was commissioned by Tiratur, who presented it to a church in the Armenian village of Tuřnach‛ay. The priest Nikōghos is remembered in two prayers (pp. 50, 208), and named the scribe in one, an indication he began writing the manuscript which Karapēt completed.

provenance.p: A prayer (p. 542) contains the name Keřas, possibly a one-time owner. University of Chicago bookplate (front doublure).

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago from H. M. Tashjian of Chicago, May 1, 1931.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

Merrill Mead Parvis, The Story of the Goodspeed Collection
([Chicago:] s.n., 1952),
pp. 18-19.
Erroll F. Rhodes, An Annotated List of Armenian New Testament Manuscripts, Annual Report of Theology 1 (1959), pp. 133-134 (1035).

New Testament manuscript traditions. An exhibition based on the Edgar J. Goodspeed Collection of the University of Chicago Library, the Joseph Regenstein Library, January-March, 1973. University of Chicago. Library. Dept. of Special Collections. Exhibition catalogs
([Chicago: s.n., 1973]), 36, no. 68.

Avedis K. Sanjian, A catalogue of medieval Armenian manuscripts in the United States
(Berkeley: University of California Press, 1976),
pp. 189-191.
